spanishExample: ¡Pon tus cosas ahí!
englishTranslation: Put your things there!
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: ¡Ponte eso! Y queremos que ella se ponga esa ropa también.
englishTranslation: Put that on! And we want her to put on those clothes too.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"
ponga: put, he/she/it put (Poner, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡Qué suerte! Dijeron que por supuesto irían.
englishTranslation: What luck! They said that of course they would go.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
irían: "would go", "they would go" (Ir, conditional, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: ¿Ella puede ponerse eso? Tú te lo pusiste y estaba bien.
englishTranslation: Can she put that on? You put it on and it was fine.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"
pusiste: put, you put (Poner, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: ¿Le has dicho lo que pones en *the food* para que tenga ese *taste?*
englishTranslation: Have you told him what you put(present) in the food so that it has that taste (m)?
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
pones: put, you put (Poner, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: ¿Puedes ponerte esa ropa nueva?
englishTranslation: Can you put on those new clothes?

spanishExample: ¿Siquiera lo has hecho? Poner eso ahí era *important.*
englishTranslation: Have you at least done it? Putting that there was important.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Cariño, dijeron que no puedes hacer eso mañana.
englishTranslation: Darling, they said you can’t do that tomorrow.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Casi todos estaban ahí por la fiesta.
englishTranslation: Almost everyone was there because of the party.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: En mi mente, eso es demasiado grande para tu casa.
englishTranslation: In my mind, that is way too big for your house.

spanishExample: Esa no es la mejor manera de ponerte la ropa, tienes que hacerlo así.
englishTranslation: That is not the best way to put the clothes on, you have to do it this way.
vocabIncluded: así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Estoy realmente triste porque le tenía mucho cariño.
englishTranslation: I’m really sad because I was very fond of her.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
tenerle cariño a alguien: to be fond of someone (idiom)

spanishExample: Hay que darle a la policía lo que *we found* ese día.
englishTranslation: There’s a need to give the police what we found that day.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
using Haber with "que" to indicate that there's a need to do something

spanishExample: Hiciste tanto hoy.
englishTranslation: You did so much today.

spanishExample: Igual, el equipo no estuvo ahí, así que me da igual.
englishTranslation: Still, the team wasn’t there, so it’s all the same to me.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
me da igual: it's all the same to me (idiom)

spanishExample: Le dimos todas nuestras cosas al hombre quien estaba ahí.
englishTranslation: We gave all our things to the man who was there.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
al: "to the" before a masculine noun
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Les *I asked* si iban a hacerlo y dijeron que por supuesto.
englishTranslation: I asked them if they were going to do it and they said that of course.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
iban: "were going", "they were going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person plural)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Lo haremos para que pongas tus cosas ahí.
englishTranslation: We’ll do it in order for you to put your things there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
haremos: "will do/make", "we will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person plural)
pongas: put, you put(Poner, subjunctive, 2nd person plural)

spanishExample: Lo hicimos antes, lo cual no fue una buena idea.
englishTranslation: We did it before, which was not a good idea.
vocabIncluded: lo cual: "which" without a specific noun (idiom)

spanishExample: Mi amiga de esa clase decía que éramos los mejores.
englishTranslation: My friend from that class used to say we were the best.
vocabIncluded: "de" to mean "of" or "from", especially in terms of origin
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
decía: "was saying", "he/she/it was saying" (Decir, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Mi madre supone que sus amigas no van a ir tampoco.
englishTranslation: My mother supposes that her friends(f) aren’t going to go either.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supone: supposes, he/she/it supposes (Suponer, present, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Muchos han tenido problemas contigo por esa razón.
englishTranslation: Many have had problems with you for that reason.
vocabIncluded: han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: No tenemos suerte porque ni siquiera quieren ir.
englishTranslation: We aren’t lucky because they don’t even want to go.

spanishExample: Póngase esto antes de irse de la casa.
englishTranslation: (formal) Put this on before leaving the house.
vocabIncluded: póngase: put on / become (Ponerse, formal imperative)

spanishExample: Pongo sus cosas en ese lugar con mucho cuidado.
englishTranslation: I’m putting her things in that place very carefully.
vocabIncluded: pongo: put, I put (Poner, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Ponlo ahí, por favor. Yo lo puse ahí antes.
englishTranslation: Put it there, please. I put it there before.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
puse: put, I put (Poner, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Por eso el equipo y yo no ponemos eso ahí.
englishTranslation: That’s why the team and I don’t put that there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
ponemos: put, we put (Poner, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Pusimos eso ahí antes porque lo habías puesto en otro lugar.
englishTranslation: We put that there before because you had put it in another place.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
habías: "had", "you had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 2nd person)
pusimos: put, we put (Poner, preterite, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Queremos que pongan las cosas que tienen ahí.
englishTranslation: We want them to put the things that they have there.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
pongan: put, they put (Poner, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Quieren que pongamos las cosas ahí porque ellos no las pusieron.
englishTranslation: They want us to put the things there because they didn’t put them.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things
pongamos: put, we put (Poner, subjunctive, 1st person plural)
pusieron: put, they put (Poner, preterite, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Quiero que lo ponga ahí después de la fiesta.
englishTranslation: I want him to put it there after the party.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
ponga: put, he/she/it put (Poner, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Quizá vayamos hoy, pero no estamos seguros.
englishTranslation: Maybe we’ll go today, but we aren’t sure.
vocabIncluded: seguro: adjective meaning "sure" when used with Estar

spanishExample: Quizás quiera ponerse lo que tú le diste.
englishTranslation: Maybe she wants to put on what you gave her.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Sabes que siempre estoy a gusto contigo.
englishTranslation: You know I’m always comfortable with you.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Se supone que tienes el amor de tu familia.
englishTranslation: Supposedly you have the love of your family.
vocabIncluded: suponerse: any use of Suponer with a reflexive, plus "que", pronoun, changing the meaning to "supposedly"

spanishExample: Se suponía que él lo puso ahí, pero no sé dónde está.
englishTranslation: Supposedly he put it there, but I don’t know where it is.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
dónde: adverb meaning "where?" in a question or implied question
puso: put, he/she/it put (Poner, preterite, 3rd person)
suponerse: any use of Suponer with a reflexive, plus "que", pronoun, changing the meaning to "supposedly"

spanishExample: Si quieres hacerlo con cariño, tienes que ponerte en su lugar.
englishTranslation: If you want to do it with affection, you have to put yourself in her shoes.
vocabIncluded: ponerse en el lugar de alguien: "to put oneself in someone's shoes" (idiom)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Siempre decimos exactamente lo mismo.
englishTranslation: We always say exactly the same thing.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"

spanishExample: Siempre pone sus cosas ahí, pero ahora quiere que yo las ponga aquí.
englishTranslation: He always puts his things there, but now he wants me to put them here.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things
pone: puts, he/she/it puts (Poner, present, 3rd person)
ponga: put, I put (Poner, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Siempre ponen las cosas en otro lugar, así que no les des nada.
englishTranslation: They always put the things in another place, so don’t give them anything.
vocabIncluded: les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
ponen:put, they put (Poner, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Siempre supone que soy el problema, así que no diré nada.
englishTranslation: He always supposes I’m the problem, so I won’t say anything.
vocabIncluded: diré: "will say", "I will say" (Decir, future, 1st person)
suponerse: any use of Suponer with a reflexive, plus "que", pronoun, changing the meaning to "supposedly"

spanishExample: Supongo que no has hecho nada aquí antes.
englishTranslation: I guess you haven’t done anything here before.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)
supongo: suppose, I suppose (Suponer, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Supuse que iba a haber paz en este lugar, pero ahora tengo miedo.
englishTranslation: I supposed there was going to be peace in this place, but now I’m afraid.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
haber: "there to be" indicating existence (Haber, infinitive)
iba: "was going", "he/she/it was going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person)
supuse: supposed, I supposed (Suponer, preterite, 1st person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Supuse que no estabas ahí y por eso lo hice.
englishTranslation: I supposed you weren’t there and that’s why I did it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
supuse: supposed, I supposed (Suponer, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Tengo que suponer que todavía no lo han hecho.
englishTranslation: I have to suppose that they still have not done it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Voy a ponerme la ropa, pero se la voy a dar de vuelta.
englishTranslation: I’m going to put the clothes on, but I’m going to give them back to her.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
